newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egypt rights group says two detained Islamists die.
newsitem.headline: Egypt rights group says two detained Islamists die.

text.p: An Egyptian human rights group said on Tuesday two detained Moslem militants died after prison authorities denied them medical treatment.
The independent Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights (EOHR) said in a statement the two men had not been convicted of any crime but were repeatedly detained for their political allegiances.
Human rights groups say Egyptian security officials use powers given to them by emergency laws in effect since 1981 to detain suspects for long periods of time without trial.
The Egyptian government is locked in a battle with Moslem militants bent on turning Egypt into a strict Islamic state.
More then 1,000 people have died since the militants launched their anti-government campaign in 1992.

The human rights group said Bakheet Abderrahman Salem, 38, died last Wednesday after officials moved him from prison hospital to a normal cell. It said torture had left him semi-paralysed, with bed sores on his legs.
Salem, married with six children, was arrested in 1993 on charges of taking part in an attack on a police checkpoint in southern Egypt. He was acquitted but was repeatedly detained.
Kamel Mohammed Mohammed Sayyed, 56, died on Saturday after authorities moved him out of a prison hospital although he was in a coma.
The rights organisation said Sayyed, repeatedly detained since August, 1993, had a kidney condition.

"The Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights (EOHR) affirms with regret that according to information and complaints it has received that prison authorities intentionally use maltreatment as a means of attacking the basic right to life of prisoners and detainees," the group said.
